Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member for the Wimmera says that the Opposition has gone home. Quite obviously the members of the Opposition are not concerned about the peopie in rural areas who have been the victims of floods Mr Thomson-And cyclones.

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: And cyclones, as the honourable member for Leichhardt says. I am indebted to him for his interjection. People also have been the victims of bushfires and locust plagues. When disasters strike, people are left in desperate situations. Quite often they are faced with great financial hardships. I believe that now is the time to consider setting up a natural disaster fund because there has been a series of serious natural disasters and people are attuned to helping in a and desperate situation. I suggest that the first step to take in attacking in this problem would be to review the formula to it under which the States and the Commonwealth In the State of Queensland, after the aU State Government has spent $2m in repairing damage caused by natural disasters any disaster which occurs and which causes damage totalling 10 per cent of that base figure of $2m is recognised as a major disaster and consequently attracts a payment from the Commonwealth Government to help the State repair government and semi-government buildings. In many instances a natural disaster can cause great damage to the property of private individuals, to businesses, to public utilities such as sporting areas, to homes, to Salvation Army homes and to nursing homes, but these institutions do not receive assistance from the Commonwealth or the State. In some cases those largely benevolent institutions do not carry sufficient insurance to allow them to replace their buildings to the standards which are necessary in a modern society. Time has passed many age pensioners by. They are not aware of the current costs of repairing damage to their roofs, windows or fibro ceilings. I suggest that governments should help aged people in this situation. I believe that this problem has come to the forefront particularly in the veryrichfarming areas of the Darling Downs in Queensland. Mr Lusher - Magnificen t country.

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: As the honourable member for Hume says, it is magnificent country. How true. Someone once said that a little bit of heaven fell out of the sky one day, and that was the Darling Downs. This area suffers from erosion particularly in the hilly country with older cultivations. We find that in areas of heavy rainfall where there is a quick fall of several inches in a short period oftimethe fertile topsoil is washed down the hills and this causes problems by silting up the streams, roadways and other public facilities. I am concerned that people do not fully realise the great cost to the nation. There is the loss of fertile soil on the one hand, which is a positive loss, but there is also the negative and that is the huge cost to shire councils and other authorities which are forced to remove many tons of silt from roads and bridges. This a national problem. People get quite emotional about the preserof vation of coloured sands, the preservation of timber in certain areas, certain tribal lands so on. Of course we of the National Country selves. Party fully support those environmental issues but the fundamental conservation procedure in Australia should be the preservation of our greatest asset-ou r soil. I hope that this Parliaand ment will be aware of the feeling in the Country Party and the Liberal Party on this vitally importhese tant matter. I hope that we will be able to instil the hearts and rninds of the Labor Parry a realisation of this great problem so that together forward we may march in an endeavour to control this great problem. I thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker, for giving me the opportunity to speak in this debate.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am indebted to the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr MCVeigh) for covering such a large scope but he has left me with so little time in which to introduce my own subject. I would like to make a few comments in connection with Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Earlier this week mention was made of certain investigations that will be made in connection with changes in this area. I am afraid that I feel that the changes will not go sufficiently far to be a real incentive to private companies which are now operating under some difficulty within the nation. For instance, increased retention allowance is proposed to be allowed but only for such things as an expansion of a capital nature. The flow-on of the recent increase of 6.4 per cent in the national wage has brought with it a particular problem for private companies in that they will require additional retentions and reserves to cover such things as increased inventories and thefinancingof debtors. I would hope that when the commission of inquiry looks at this aspect it will look further than leaving retentions only for an expansion of a capital nature. I hope it will loss, as it were, look into other areas. I also suggest in relation to the Income Tax is Assessment Act that we might look at the problem of the one-income family. It was mentioned that an option would be granted to shareholders private companies to be assessed on a partnership basis. I think we should go further and look and at the incidence of taxation on families themA social problem is created where there is only one income earner. If extra money is required someone from the family is sent out to work. This is usually the wife and the mother, this does create a social problem. I would hope that we would have a complete review of matters. I hope that we can give some relief into these families which now suffer and also bring about the end of that social disease known as latch-key children.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mr Drummond)Order! It being 11 p.m., the House stands adjourned until Tuesday, 16 March 1976 at 2.15 p.m. unless Mr Speaker shall, by telegram or letter addressed to each member of the House, fix an earlier day of meeting. House adjourned at 11 p.m. The following answers to questions

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice: (1) Have any arrangements been finalised with the States to allow for only one meat inspecting authority for local and export purposes at all meat works. (2) Is the present system of dual inspections, by both the States and the Commonwealth, both wasteful and unnecessary. (3) What would be the saving by the industry and the Government in one year if there was a single authority.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No. Meat inspection arrangements in Australia are at present under consideration by the Administrative Review Committee chaired by Sir Henry Bland. On receipt of the Committee's report further discussions will take place with the States. (2) The Commonwealth responsibilities relate to export inspection but because all export establishments place products on the domestic market, the States have an interest in export establishments. The involvement of State's staff differs between the States. In the States where dual or joint meat inspection services operate some extra costs are incurred. (3) It is not possible to specify the savings to industry and to the Government that would ensue if there were a single authority responsible for meat would require legislative acuon by the Commonwealth and the States and actual savings would depend on a number of factors including the acceptability of a single brand for export and home consumption, continuation or removal of State inspection charges and elimination of different terms and conditions of employment for meat inspectors. Wheat Prices Stabilization Fund Mr MCVeigh asked the Minister for Primary Industiy, upon notice: (1) What were growers' contributions to the Wheat Stabilization Fund for 1973-74 and 1974-75, and what is the estimated contribution for 1975-76. State and Division New South WalesBanks Barton Bennelong Berowra Blaxland Bradfield Calare Chifley Cook Cowper NA upon notice were circulated: Meat Inspection (2) If the growers' contributions plus interest for the years 1973-74 and 1974-75 exceeded S80m, when, and to which (Question No. 70) growers, will this surplus be distributed and how much will be distributed.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The growers' contribution to the Wheat Prices Stabilization Fund in respect of the 1973-74 season's pool was $48.5m. A contribution of $30m (being the ceiling contribution from a pool under the current stabilization plan) will be made against the 1974-75 pool in the next two or three months once the pool accounting is finalised. The growers'contribution from the 1975-76 pool is not due to be made until the pool's exports are shipped and the accounting is complete, that is, in about twelve months or so. It is likely that growers will again be required to make the maximum payment of $30m but this cannot be stated with certainty as some of the pool's export wheat is not yet priced. (2) There will be a relatively small amount ($4 to 5m) in excess of the $80m ceiling once the $30m from the 1974-75 pool is paid. In accordance with the legislation which provides that Fund accruals exceeding $80m are to be refunded on a 'first-infirstout' basis, the distribution of the surplus referred to will be to the 1973-74 season's pool. It is expected that payment to the Wheat Board in respect of interest would be made in 2 or 3 months time while payment to the Board as the result of the expected contribution for the 1975-76 pool would be about this time next year.
